awd_titl_txt: Macromolecular-bottlebrush polymeric gels with tissue-mimetic swelling and mechanical properties
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Living tissues are distinct in their ability to seamlessly span a range of mechanical properties from ultra-soft brain to super-tough cartilage at nearly constant water fraction. On the contrary, synthetic analogs of tissues (i.e. polymeric gels) are currently not capable to control the amount of water without affecting their mechanics.  A new class of polymeric materials based on bottlebrush-macromolecular architectures is proposed here to enable independent and programmable control over gel composition and mechanical properties.  In contrast to traditional linear polymers, the bottlebrush architecture introduces a myriad of side chains or “bristles” that afford additional molecular parameters to tune softness without changing the water fraction. Furthermore, tailoring the chemistry of side-chain ends will empower novel applications such as programmable and injectable materials for additive manufacturing of tissue-mimetic devices. The proposed novel class of polymeric gels will provide ample opportunities for interdisciplinary research through integration of cutting-edge polymer chemistry, soft-matter physics, and emerging technologies that may lead to breakthroughs in many applications such as biomedical devices, tissue-engineering scaffolds, and soft robotics. 


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The project will address three fundamental challenges. First, the equilibrium swelling ratio and gel’s mechanical properties will be separately correlated with architectural parameters of brush-like networks such as the side chain length and grafting density. Triangulation of architecture-swelling-mechanics correlations will afford independent control over swelling, softness, and non-linear mechanical response. For example, this will create an unprecedented series of synthetic gels with the same solvent fraction, but widely different moduli varying within several orders of magnitude. The second goal is to design brush-like mesoblocks that enable solvent-free injection of tissue-mimetic elastomers. The challenge is to control curing time from seconds to days separate from mechanical properties of fully cured polymer networks. Lastly, successful implementation of goals 1 and 2 will enable a new class of bioink materials based on thermosensitive hydrogels that can inject and 3D-print objects with well-defined solvent fractions and mechanical properties. The main challenge here is to integrate controlled-temperature gelation of printed materials with the design-by-architecture objectives pursued in goals 1 and 2.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. Living tissues are distinct in their ability to seamlessly span a range of mechanical properties from ultra-soft brain to super-tough cartilage at nearly constant water fraction. On the contrary, conventional synthetic gels are not able to adjust their mechanics without affecting the water content.  Herein, we leveraged the brush-like polymer architecture to enable independent and programmable control over gel composition and mechanical properties. In contrast to traditional linear polymers, the bottlebrush architecture introduces a myriad of side chains that afford additional structural parameters to tune softness without changing the degree of swelling. Furthermore, tailoring the chemistry of side-chain ends empowers minimally invasive injection capability for both direct injection to the body and additive manufacturing of biomedical devices.


Research activities were focused on fundamental understanding of physical correlations between the brush architectural parameters, equilibrium swelling ratio, and mechanical properties. We developed novel physical principles that allow decoupling gel modulus, firmness, and swellability, mimicking Nature’s ability to vary mechanical properties of tissues at constant swelling ratio. Notably, mechanically diverse gels at a given solvent content were prepared without altering chemical composition. We developed a versatile platform for the design of injectable elastomers and gels possessing tissue-mimetic softness, tunable within a broad range from fat tissue to muscle tissue. The developed principles of side-chain functionalization have been employed for the design of reversible thermosets, possessing both upcycling and circularity capabilities, where a polymer network can either reconfigure into a new product or reversibly disassemble to its constituent building blocks. The developed knowledge has been used to unveil the origin of heat- and desiccation-tolerance tardigrade proteins owing to a ‘molecular shield’ provided by the sur-rounding gel. In total, 24 refereed articles, and 1 patent application were produced. Fundamental findings were reported in top scientific journals, including Nature Materials, Nature Communications, Science Advances, ACS Central Science, Materials Horizons, and Advanced Materials.


Broader Impact. The work on the design of tissue-mimetic gels with architecturally programmable properties built a robust platform for interdisciplinary research through integration of cutting-edge polymer chemistry, soft-matter physics, and emerging technologies in personalized medicine, soft robotics, and wearable electronics. A new technology was developed, where tissue-mimetic elastomers and gels can be injected non-invasively to the body to match both mechanics and water content of the surrounding tissue (patent pending). The project provided maximum opportunity for (i) integrating science and education, (ii) enhancing diversity, and (iii) fostering infrastructure for collaborative research.  The most essential accomplishments include a) Interdisciplinary training: working at the interface of Organic Chemistry, Soft-Matter Physics, and Biomedical Engineering, all students received training in precision synthesis, physical characterization, and theoretical analysis; b) Integration Research and Education. The obtained results on gel property control by molecular architecture have been incorporated into class and lab modules; c) Participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. This award sponsored 3 graduate and 2 undergraduate students. From this group, we successfully recruited and trained 3 female students, including a Hispanic graduate student receiving a Fellowship from the Eastman Chemical Company in recognition to student’s commitment to promoting diversity and inclusion; d) Partnership with industry (Lululemon Athletica, Abbvie, and Jurata Thin Films companies) on diverse applications, including coloration of tissue-mimetic textiles, reconstructive surgery, and vaccine encapsulation; e) International collaborations between UNC, CNRS (France), and the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility.


Last Modified: 07/28/2024
Modified by: Sergei S Sheiko
